text:
Bedford Street, east side, south from and including Morton Street, showing across the vacant lot at the N.E. corner (former No. 60-62), the Bedford M.E. Church at the S.E. corner. This was demolished when Seventh Ave. was cut through and would today (1937) be in the center of Seventh Ave. where Morton and Bedford Streets intersect. Buildings on the left are Nos. 64 and 66 Bedford Street, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Morton Street and are frame houses with brick fronts. They stand today and adjoining a 6-story apartment house at the corner.

1914.

(1)
Junk shop in an old house at 16 Morton Street, south side, between Bedford and Bleecker Streets, adjoining the five-story tenement No. 14 Morton Street. About 1915.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

(2)
18, 16, 14 Morton Street, south side of eastern section, between Bedford and Bleecker Streets and just east of Seventh Avenue South. This view shows the entire house at 16 Morton Street, which since the date of the old picture has had a doorway cut where two windows used to be. The garage at 18-20 Morton Street is quite new, probably only three or four years old.
May 19, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Junk shop in an old house at 16 Morton Street, south side, between Bedford and Bleecker Streets, adjoining the five-story tenement No. 14 Morton Street. About 1915.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

(2)
18, 16, 14 Morton Street, south side of eastern section, between Bedford and Bleecker Streets and just east of Seventh Avenue South. This view shows the entire house at 16 Morton Street, which since the date of the old picture has had a doorway cut where two windows used to be. The garage at 18-20 Morton Street is quite new, probably only three or four years old.
May 19, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Bedford Street, northeast side, north from Morton Street (the eastern part, originally Ardens Street). Nos. 64-70, the four old houses in the middle of the first block, are frame buildings faced with brick.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

Bedford Street, southwest side, from Morton (originally Ardens) Street to Commerce Street, from Seventh Avenue South. The pavement in the foreground is exactly on the site of the Bedford Street Methodist Church, which was demolished when Seventh Avenue South was cut through in 1915.

March 29, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
